hints.title: Regge Calculus Convergence (Standard Result)
hints.content:
94: :label: thm-regge-convergence
95: 
96: Let $(M, g)$ be a smooth Riemannian manifold. Let $\mathcal{T}_N$ be a sequence of triangulations (or Voronoi tessellations) of $M$ with mesh size $\delta_N \to 0$ as $N \to \infty$.
97: 
98: Define the **deficit angle** $\theta_e$ on each edge (or plaquette) $e$ of the tessellation. Then:
99: 
100: $$
101: \lim_{\delta_N \to 0} \frac{\text{(deficit angle sum around point)}}{\text{(local volume)}} = R_{\mu\nu}[g]
102: $$
103: 
104: where $R_{\mu\nu}[g]$ is the Ricci curvature tensor of the smooth metric $g$.
105: 
106: **References**:
107: - Regge, T. (1961). "General relativity without coordinates". *Nuovo Cimento* **19**, 558-571.
hints.raw_directive:
91: The connection between discrete geometry (scutoids) and continuum geometry (Riemannian metric) is rigorously established by **Regge calculus**, a formulation of general relativity on piecewise-flat simplicial complexes.

99: 
100: $$
101: \lim_{\delta_N \to 0} \frac{\text{(deficit angle sum around point)}}{\text{(local volume)}} = R_{\mu\nu}[g]
102: $$
103: 
104: where $R_{\mu\nu}[g]$ is the Ricci curvature tensor of the smooth metric $g$.
105:

107: - Regge, T. (1961). "General relativity without coordinates". *Nuovo Cimento* **19**, 558-571.
108: - Cheeger, J., Müller, W., Schrader, R. (1984). "On the curvature of piecewise flat spaces". *Comm. Math. Phys.* **92**, 405-454.
